captions.text:
Let me briefly describe the difference between
a quantum computer and a regular computer,

at some level. In a regular computer, you've
got ones and zeros, which you store in binary

form and you manipulate them and they do calculations.
You can store them, for example, in a way
that at least I can argue simply.

Let's say you have an elementary particle
that's spinning. If it's spinning, and we

say it's spinning, it's pointing up or down
depending upon whether it's spinning this

way or this way, pointing up or down. And
so, I could store the information by having

lots of particles and some of them spinning
up and some of them spinning down. Right?
One's and zero's.

But in the quantum world, it turns out that
particles like electrons are actually spinning

in all directions at the same time, one of
the weird aspects of quantum mechanics. We

may measure, by doing a measurement of an
electron, find it's spinning this way. But

before we did the measurement, it was spinning
this way and this way and that way and that

way all at the same time. Sounds crazy, but
true.

Now that means, if the electron's spinning
in many different directions at the same time,

if we don't actually measure it, it can be
doing many computations at the same time.

And so a quantum computer is based on manipulating
the state of particles like electrons so that

during the calculation, many different calculations
are being performed at the same time, and

only making a measurement at the end of the
computation.

So we exploit that fact of quantum mechanics
that particles could do many things at the

same time to do many computations at same
time. And that's what would make a quantum
computer so powerful.

One of the reasons it's so difficult to make
a quantum computer, and one of the reasons

I'm a little skeptical at the moment, is that
- the reason the quantum world seems so strange

to us is that we don't behave quantum mechanically.
I don't -- you know, you can - not me, but

you could run towards the wall behind us from
now 'til the end of the universe and bang

your head in to it and you'd just get a tremendous
headache. But if you're an electron, there's

a probability if I throw it towards the wall
that it will disappear and appear on the other

side due to something called quantum tunneling,
okay.

Those weird quantum behaviors are manifest
on small scales. We don't obey them - have

those behaviors 'cause we're large classical
objects and the laws of quantum mechanics

tell us, in some sense, that when you have
many particles interacting at some level those

weird quantum mechanical correlations that
produce all the strange phenomena wash away.

And so in order to have a quantum mechanical
state where you can distinctly utilize and

exploit those weird quantum properties, in
some sense you have to isolate that system

from all of its environment because, if it
interacts with the environment, the quantum
mechanical weirdness sort of washes away.

And that's the problem with a quantum computer.
You want to make this macroscopic object,

you want to keep it behaving quantum mechanically
which means isolating it very carefully from,

within itself, all the interactions and the
outside world. And that's the hard part, Is

isolating things enough to maintain this what's
called quantum coherence. And that's the challenge
and it's a huge challenge.

But the potential is unbelievably great. Once
you can engineer materials on a scale where

quantum mechanical properties are important,
a whole new world of phenomenon open up to

you. And you might be able to say - as we
say, if we created a quantum computer, and

I'm not - I must admit I'm skeptical that
we'll be able to do that in the near-term,

but if we could, we'd be able to do computations
in a finite time that would take longer than

the age of the universe right now. We'd be
able to do strange and wonderful things. And

of course, if you ask me what's the next big
breakthrough, I'll tell you what I always

tell people, which is if I knew, I'd be doing
it right now.

comments.text:
Could quantum tunneling be what is causing an electron to seem as if it is 
spinning in every direction at once? Imagine this... NASA sends a drone 
with a quantum computer to somewhere too hot for quantum tunneling. Would 
that, ''Supercharge,'' the quantum computing process. Or would it destroy 
it. How come there are only adults explaining quantum computing? 12 year 
olds like me should be learning about this, not social studies and music 
and all that crap. This is more important in every circumstance. The 
education system should have at least the slightest bit of common sense 
when it comes to something this important.﻿
comments.author: Jeff Witt

comments.text:
Our level of Technology and understanding of Science is growing 
exponentially. There is no telling what future technology will be like.   
In the near future computers will begin to think (Not True AI) but they 
will have the capability of doing actual research and engineering. 

These computers will have instant access to all of Human Knowledge.   A 
person like Krause may just have to ask the computer a profound question 
like what is the best theory of the Universe.  

This computer will go do research, create Models/Simulations, New physics 
and come to a solution.   In matter of minutes these computers could 
advance our understanding of Cosmology by Decades if not Centuries. 

Of course Krause wouldn't be out of work. You still need people to 
understand the results so they can ask new questions.

 This would extend to all fields of Science and Engineering.

 We of course would need to make new Observations and build new tools. 
  Again Smart Manufacturing, 3D Printing would speed things up drastically. 
Expensive projects that take decades, could be done in Months and at a 
fraction of the cost.

No computer is going to spit out the designs for a Warp Drive. If a warp 
drive is possible it may only take Decades to build not Centuries. 

Provided no major Cataclysm happens like a Nuclear War, The next 100 years 
could see advances that we thought would take thousands of years. Really 
just look at the last 100 years. 

That includes Medical advances so some of us may even be around to Witness 
it. People born today may be the last generation that has to face death. 
Hell they may even be first people to colonize the Solar System and Galaxy. 

Technology that Ends World Hunger, Poverty and Momentary systems. 3 of the 
Leading causes of Crime and War. Technology the restores the environment 
and ecosystems. So all life can have a chance.   

Possibilities are Endless.﻿

comments.author: G.M D.B.

comments.text:
+G.M D.B. First, powerful means it can potentially solve 
new/greater/different problems than a normal computer. We know a quantum 
computer is still a Turing machine, therefore it cannot solve a whole new 
set of problems - Thus not more powerful.
Secondly, I said its better at solving a certain set of problems - Better 
meaning it will take less time. A particular interesting set of problems it 
can solve better is called NP-complete. NP are problems solvable in 
polynomial time with a non-deterministic Turing machine. The essential 
point here is, if a problem can be solved in polynomial time, we(as humans) 
can actually live to see the result.
Now, I'm not going to give you a full lecture on youtube, so if you are 
more interested in the field of computer science, and particularly what 
computers can and cannot do, I'd recommend start reading books about theory 
of computations.

comments.author: BW022

comments.text:
+Candle light Correct. Even Wikipedia article says that D-Wave was 
debunked. And that is what anyone can find on the internet in less than 60 
seconds (literally). And the peer review papers are sourced there. So you 
can click them and read that the "serious researchers" actually found 
D-Wave to have. and I quote...
"
likely the most thorough and precise study that has been done on the 
performance of the D-Wave machine"[51] and "the fairest comparison yet", 
found that the D-Wave chip "produced no quantum speedup".[52] The 
researchers, led by Matthias Troyer at the Swiss Federal Institute of 
Technology, found "no quantum evidence" across the entire range of their 
tests, and only inconclusive results when looking at subsets of the tests."
And that is one of 66 findings out of 68 that were done that all agree in 
the non-quantum-computing-state. The remaining two didn't even say it was a 
positive, they were inconclusive. Zero actual evidence to support its 
claim. And D-Wave knows it. But they can still say they have one because of 
the legal system. It allows them to garnish millions of dollars from 
uneducated benefactors.
comments.author: mathew entson

comments.text:
+BW022 no they haven't. Not one of those are actually quantum computers. 
Even the companies were forced to admit this once "Fraud claims yielding 
benefactors" was filed.
D-wave came the closest. But they never actually established "isolated 
cohesion". So, they still use "normal" computers to help direct 
computations and probabilities.
Not one company has built an actual quantum computer that in-and-of-itself 
does all the work.
To be absolutely clear, There have been "quantum computations" that have 
been completed. The world record is 5x3=15. As of right now, In feb 2015 
Ibm is trying to break that record by getting into math problems that end 
in a 3 digit answer. That's extremely tough. I know it sounds basic and 
"meh". But it's impressive if you know the science involved. 
Now I bring this up because they didn't "technically" quantumly compute 
that outcome. They told the electrons to "not" spin a certain way at a 
certain time. (still allowing for millions of permutations of it's 
position). By doing so they broke the "coherence" right off the bat. They 
only did this in order to test if quantum decoherence could be 
"controlled". Thus, giving us the outcome we desired. Just like we program 
computers with 1 and 0's in order to give us the results we want, they 
programmed atoms to "fail" in a specific way so the end result would be 
met. It's more of a "proof of concept" than "physical success". 
Sorry if this got confusing.. I can't think of a simpler way to explain it. 
And that's probably my fault.
comments.author: Candle light

comments.text:
No. I didn't. It's a "fact" (not an opinion) on what I said about the 
Quantum Decoherence. It 100% means that it isn't a "real" Q computer. It is 
only a Virtual Q-computer. You don't know the difference. I do.
And because you seemed to miss the thing I was getting at, I happen to be 
one of those people who investigates these computers for this EXACT claim.
And to further explain...A company is allowed to say they have a Quantum 
Computer "legally" because the legal understanding and requirement of a 
computer to be a Q-computer is different then what a physicist would 
require. Even though it isn't one, they can still call it one. It's 
actually very common in the industry to do this. Much like when a company 
says Zero Fat on a product, but in reality it is very fattening because of 
semantics and legal loopholes.
I said a fact that outright proves that it isn't a Q computer. Not an 
opinion. Ironically, you are the person spouting off conjecture. I.e. You 
are giving me your opinions and zero facts. 
I.e you believing what people would do when faced with "flaws" in a paper. 
It's your opinion they would shred them. When, in reality, they don't have 
to shred anything because afforded to them by legal loopholes and semantics 
D Wave is allowed to say "we have a Q-Computer". But they are allowed to 
leave out that it's only a virtual one. And because of that you believe 
them. They fooled you. 
And to double up on the irony here, you are telling "me" what those 
researchers found. 
Again, I point out that I AM ONE OF THOSE RESEARCHERS. 
You're telling ME what I found...And only one of us has multiple degrees 
and one masters involving the subject.
You're off point.
Cheers, though.
comments.author: mathew entson

comments.text:
You didn't state any facts. You stated your opinions. At least three major 
universities disagree with your D-Wave claim. They state that the D-Wave is 
a quantum computer.That is their opinion. Everyone now gets to decide whose 
opinion is most likely to be correct -- the physics/engineering departments 
of three major universities who have actually had access and tested the 
machines and had peer reviewed papers published on it.

If it was anything close to a fact, anyone reading the papers with any 
authority would have found serious flaws and shredded them. They would 
either never have been published or would have been withdrawn.
comments.author: BW022

comments.text:
It isn't a Q computer. I've explained factually how it isn't. You restating 
your previous comment does nothing.
Also, you admit "random internet" guy "could" be anyone. So it doesn't do 
well to try to undermine me if you're already admitting I could be a person 
who investigates exactly this claim...thus lending me a credibility far 
above any "serious researcher" you've mentioned.
I post on these in a lot of youtube videos of similar nature. I do it for a 
reason, and with evidence. I'm sure you can click my user name and see them

It's almost like it's my job to be in a group of people who are paid to 
investigate the authenticity of whether or not the atoms are truly 
isolated, or only virtually isolated (which D-Waves are).
comments.author: mathew entson

comments.text:
Both papers from Caltech and USC are online. I'll allow people to read them

comments.author: BW022

comments.text:
Companies have been "claiming" to have invented the quantum computer since 
1994. A Quantum Computer by definition has to seed itself. A traditional 
computer doing so disrupts the "Quantum Coherence". Once A Q-computer 
experience Quantum Decoherence it can not be a Q-computer. They all know 
this and admit this takes place. So far it is impossible to separate the 
cored atoms from surrounding external matter.
"serious researchers" are met with other "serious researchers" in physical 
and metaphysical (virtual particle based evidence) that this isn't an 
actual Q computer.
comments.author: mathew entson

comments.text:
+mathew entson Says who? Google, NSA, Lockheed, etc. say it is. CalTech 
says it is. USC says it probably is. Any quantum computer has to be 
'seeded' (whatever your definition of that is) by a non-quantum system.

Serious researchers have all concluded that given D-Wave's results, the 
theory behind it, and its construction... it is now up to people to proof 
that is doesn't work -- and give alternate explanations of how a 
non-quantum system can give the same results.
comments.author: BW022

comments.text:
it isn't a 100% quantum computer.  It still uses traditional computation to 
seed itself.
A quantum computer has not yet been fully invented.
comments.author: mathew entson

comments.text:
They already exist. D-Wave has built and is selling a series based on 
q-bits formed from rings of material containing a tiny packet 
trapped super-cooled gas. When a magnetic field is sent through the tiny 
space, the poles of the gases align and induce a tiny current in the ring. 
D-Wave has a computer with 512 q-bits. Costs $10M+ per machine and they've 
sold them to the US military, weather service, and others.

comments.text:
we measure the probability of finding an electron in a given infinitesimal

comments.text:
no they haven't. Not one of those are actually quantum computers. Even the 
companies were forced to admit this once "Fraud claims yielding 
benefactors" was filed.
D-wave came the closest. But they never actually established "isolated 
cohesion". So, they still use "normal" computers to help direct 
computations and probabilities.
Seriously, I check this stuff for a living, not one company has built an 
actual quantum computer that in-and-of-itself does all the work.
To be absolutely clear, There have been "quantum computations" that have 
been completed. The world record is 5x3=15. As of right now, In feb 2015 
Ibm is trying to break that record by getting into math problems that end 
in a 3 digit answer. That's extremely tough. I know it sounds basic and 
"meh". But it's impressive if you know the science involved. 
Now I bring this up because they didn't "technically" quantumly compute 
that outcome. They told the electrons to "not" spin a certain way at a 
certain time. (still allowing for millions of permutations of it's 
position). By doing so they broke the "coherence" right off the bat. They 
only did this in order to test if quantum decoherence could be 
"controlled". (and if you don't have coherence, by definition, you are not 
a "Quantum Computer") Thus, giving us the outcome we desired. Just like we 
program computers with 1 and 0's in order to give us the results we want, 
they programed atoms to "fail" in a specific way so the end result would be 
met. 
Sorry if this got confusing.. I can't think of a simpler way to explain it. 
And that's probably my fault.

comments.author: James Lewis

comments.text:
Well, I'd say his skepticism is completely justified. Making a quantum 
computer work is a nontrivial challenge. But there are two kinds of 
"skepticism" about quantum computers floating around, and it's important to 
distinguish them:

1) The one that notes that decoherence is a difficult hurdle to be 
overcome, and that even with quantum error correction it'll take a while to 
iron out the kinks in the technology. But this kind recognizes that the 
science of quantum computers is just regular, ordinary quantum mechanics, 
and that we have no reason to doubt that it's possible in principle.
2) The people who have a knee jerk reaction against the concept. For 
whatever reason, they have decided that quantum computers are impossible 
and that something in quantum mechanics must break down to prove that it's 
not possible.

Needless to say, (2) is pseudoscientific bullcrap (even though it would be 
very interesting if quantum mechanics broke down in such a way, we just 
don't have any evidence that that's true). Position (1) is what Krauss is 
talking about, and an opinion I share. We must not confuse arguing against 
the kind of pseudoscience in argument (2) with arguing against the concept 
of quantum computers in general. The *reasons* why you call yourself a 
skeptic are important.

And then, there's D-wave's machine, which is not a quantum computer at all, 
and therefore exempt of Krauss's skepticism. I blame it on their marketing 
department for advertising it as something it's not.
comments.author: gogerychwyrndrobwll

comments.text:
+gogerychwyrndrobwll TBH, I'm responding to the excessive focus in this 
thread about the word 'sceptical'... Surely that would be the right 
position for a technology which has never actually been realised, and may 
never be... I'm certainly sceptical about fusion being able to deliver on 
its promises on a timescale which makes it useful in an effort against 
pollution or global warming...... for example.

As for the explanation, there are more technically accurate, and more 
complete ones.... But I thought this was more accessible than most, 
detailed enough... But not so complex that my mother can't understand it, 
that makes it more useful than most.
comments.author: James Lewis

comments.text:
+James Lewis What exactly are you replying to?

I understand a thing or two about quantum computing myself, though I'm by 
no means an expert. Krauss's explanation was decent. But you can clearly 
tell it is not his field. And that's *okay*, his expertise lies elsewhere, 
and he's done a lot of cool stuff. I don't know who else tried to explain 
it and how good a job they did; if I had to bet on who could do it if 
asked, I'd say either John Preskill or Umesh Vazirani.

All in all, quantum computing is a tricky subject to summarize. Algorithms 
that are simple enough to explain are for silly and artificial problems, 
and problems with practical application have really complicated algorithms.
comments.author: gogerychwyrndrobwll

comments.text:
+gogerychwyrndrobwll dude, he said he was 'sceptical', i'd say that's a 
fairly reasonable position at present.... I don't think anyone can say for 
certain if practical quantum computing will ever be possible, although we 
can always hope..... Of course there are people who are more qualified to 
speak specifically about the potential for future applications, but it 
doesn't change the fact that the video is a good clear summary of the 
concept (certainly one of the best), from someone who understands it far 
better than any presenter on a science show who might have tried.
comments.author: James Lewis

comments.text:
+James Lewis No, really, quantum computing is a different beast. Lawrence 
Krauss is a very smart guy and a very competent physicist, but quantum 
computing isn't just something you pick up automatically from knowing 
quantum mechanics. That doesn't mean he can't know a thing or two about it, 
but it does mean that there are experts in the field out there who would be 
more qualified to discuss it.
comments.author: gogerychwyrndrobwll

comments.text:
+gogerychwyrndrobwll Actually he's a theoretical physicist who's had a lot 
to do with quantum mechanics writing several books on that and related 
subjects, and working with a number of people who have received nobel 
prizes in related areas... not least Richard Feynman... over the last 30 
years researching in areas such as gravity and dark matter which are 
largely based on quantum physics...
Agreed he's not a quantum computing specialist, but if you'd spent 30 years 
researching semiconductors you might know a thing or two about what types 
of uses they might be put to.
comments.author: James Lewis

comments.text:
+James Lewis Probably not, he's a physicist but not a quantum computing 
specialist. Most physicists don't know the first thing about quantum 
computing, apart from the very basic principles that it shares with more 
mainstream applications of quantum mechanics.

 
+Daniel Bull"Skeptical but positive" is probably how I'd describe myself 
also. I mean, the concept of quantum annealing is really cool. I'm not 
necessarily convinced that it works well for enough search problems to be 
lucrative -- heuristics tend to be very finicky and often have to be tailor 
made, hence why these problems are hard problems -- but it's an interesting 
scientific demonstration if nothing else.
comments.author: gogerychwyrndrobwll

comments.author: James Lewis

comments.text:
Hmm, OK fair enough. So what you are saying is the DWave is a Quantum 
Computing device but not a general purpose Quantum Computer. 

By the way Scott seemed to changed his mind once he used the computer but I 
think this is before your article....
From Wikipedia "Aaronson in May 2011 updated his views, announcing that he 
was "retiring as Chief D-wave Skeptic" in 2011, and reporting his 
"skeptical but positive" views based on a visit to D-Wave in February 2012. 
"
comments.author: Daniel Bull

comments.text:
+Daniel Bull Scott Aaronson (http://www.scottaaronson.com/blog/?p=1400 )has 
been quite vocal about it, and so has Umesh Vazirani, to name a couple. 
These are some of the foremost quantum computing researchers, mind you, not 
some random guys off the street. 

Of course D-Wave would advertise themselves that way, but you have to read 
the fine print. Their product is not a general purpose quantum computer 
like the one Krauss is describing here. It cannot do the things that 
quantum computers are touted for, like factoring with Shor's algorithm or 
searches with Grover's algorithm.

What it does is a process called "quantum annealing". The idea is that you 
encode a hard optimization problem in a certain quantum system in such a 
way that the state of lowest energy gives you the answer. You let the 
system evolve, and then it's hoped that quantum mechanical tunneling will 
help the system reach its lowest energy state without being trapped in 
local minima that represent good, but not optimal, solutions to your 
problem.

The idea is sound, and much good science has been done about it. But it has 
caveats when it comes to implementation. In particular, even though they 
claimed that their machine already gives results faster than a classical 
computer would, they were rather embarrassingly disproved by a relatively 
unoptimized python script.

It's also difficult to know what exactly is going on and if their data is 
reliable - you can't exactly trust their press releases. All in all, it 
seems reasonable to say that they achieved some pretty remarkable 
experimental results in regards to implementing quantum systems, but so far 
it has not produced the desired speedups.

It's an interesting technological avenue and I hope they do something cool 
with it, but calling it a quantum computer is just not accurate.
comments.author: gogerychwyrndrobwll

comments.text:

isn't a chance that it's anywhere in the universe until you measure it...it 
actually IS everywhere in the universe at the same time until you measure 
it. Might not sound like a big difference, but it is.

An electron is spin up AND spin down until measured. However, there's a 
varying probability of you finding it in one state than the others.
comments.author: tylerboydrules

comments.text: +Robert Bonino That actually makes a lot of sense to me, not sure why.
comments.author: Ami Blackwelder

comments.text:
What the guys before me said. To my understanding the electron is moving in 
every direction at once, its not till be do the measurement we determine 
which one. The famos analogy is Schrodinger's cat
comments.author: Sam Watts

comments.text:
It IS actually in different states. We know this through experiments like 
the Double Slit (Go watch some youtube videos on it.). Until you measure a 
quantum particle, it has the chance to be everywhere in the universe. 
Literally.
comments.author: Robert B

comments.text:
What I heard before is that an electron actually is in several states at 
the same time (spinning different directions and different places).

But when it comes to contact with large objects like us, it stablizes into 
one state (one spinning dir. and one pos.), so the idea is letting 
different states perform different calculations at the same time.

comments.text: One of my favorite authors: Lawrence Krauss. He wrote a great book on the physics of Star Trek. It's amazing to see how science fiction led to science fact on so many levels. comments.text:
+phoboskitty m You say this as though he's just making stuff up off the top 
of his head. As though he hasn't talked to quantum computing engineers and 
scientists about this, or studied their books, published papers, journals, 
etc. You speak as though his ability to understand and interpret the 
information he has gathered from experts is just like any other person 
walking down the street. When in fact he is an incredibly smart scientist 
who also has the rare ability to take this information and communicate it 
in terms non scientists can understand. He's not speaking as an authority, 
he never said he was. He's explaining something he knows from the studies 
he has done from other scientist's research. Your point is that he is not 
an expert in the field... thats a really insignificant and strange point to 
make here.
